HOW IS YOUR HEART... YOUR LITERAL HEART, THIS VALENTINE'S?

In this era of lockdowns and isolation, Netflix and chill has become our biggest past time activity. In the numerous movies and documentaries that we have watched, the one hospital machinery that can almost never miss is the electrocardiograph machine or simply ECG. You know the screen that has a line that goes up and down and when it flatlines there is that loud annoying sound that comes on and we know our favourite character is about to die? Yes, that one! It is a machine that monitors the heart's electrical activity and rhythm. There is a standard ECG tracing considered normal which contains a P wave, QRS complex and T wave. The mentioned waves may have abnormalities which can be indicative of abnormal functioning of the heart. Worse still, which you have seen time and again in the movies, it can flatline which calls for immediate medical attention.
Globally, inclusive of Kenya, one of the major non communicable diseases that has the highest morbidity and mortality rate is heart disease. These include hypertension, coronary heart disease, arrhythmia, peripheral artery disease, stroke, cardiac arrest, heart failure and congenital heart disease.

Some of the signs that indicate that you could be in need of a cardiologist are chest pain, breathlessness, palpitations, dizziness or blackouts just to mention a few. Chest pain that feels as though there is tightness around your chest and spreads to your arms, neck and jaw in particular, is one pertinent sign that you cannot afford to ignore. This is because it could indicate that you are having angina, a warning sign that if not promptly attended to you stand a risk of having a heart attack or stroke. These could be fatal.

What can we do to protect ourselves and our loved ones from heart disease then? This can be broadly categorised as preventative, diagnostic and curative. Prevention is better than cure and our nutrition has the lions share in protecting us from heart disease. Having a balanced diet with plenty of vegetables and less of high cholesterol foods such as fast foods is standard. Avoiding smoking and heavy alcohol intake is also important. With the right diet we can avoid obesity and diabetes which are major risk factors of heart disease. Physical exercise is another lifestyle change that can go a long way in safeguarding our hearts. A simple walk, jog or moderately strenuous activity as often as possible is recommended.

Unfortunately, some of us have years of poor habits that we may not be able to easily undo. For this, early diagnosis is advised. Having a regular visit with your cardiologist to ensure everything is okay is ideal. In the event an abnormality is noted, there are many treatments available which your cardiologist will advise accordingly.
